<plain_text><page sequence="1">1968 MLA INTERNATIONAL BIBLIOGRAPHY OF BOOKS AND ARTICLES ON THE MODERN LANGUAGES AND LITERATURES Compiled by HARRISON T. MESEROLE Association Bibliographer Assisted by those whose names appear in the list of contributors.</page><page sequence="2">1968 MLA INTERNATIONAL BIBLIOGRAPHY THE following bibliography is the thirteenth one of international coverage published by the Modern Language Association. Like its predecessor, the "Annual Bibliography for 1967," it has been compiled from a basic master list of about 1,300 periodicals central to the field, and from various book sources. Its compilers have been guided by the stipulations of the MLA Executive Council, which specified for inclusion "books and articles written in English, French, German, Spanish, Italian, Portuguese, Rumanian, Scandinavian, Dutch, Celtic, and a selection of 10 East European languages." Selective representative sections in Medieval and Neo-Latin, Modern Greek, Oriental, and African literatures have been included also. The bibliography is not an exhaustive gathering of every comment resulting from thorough search in all periodicals and book sources. Selection has been made of contributions useful to scholars in the field of modern languages and literatures. The master list, which precedes the bibliography, differs somewhat from that published in the June 1968 listing. The changes reflect recommendations from the members of the Committee who have actually been working with the periodicals. Occasionally, however, important scholarly articles appearing in journals not central to the field of modern languages and literatures have been listed with full documentation, although the journals themselves are not included in the master list. This list is subject to change as occasion warrants, but must remain compassable within the limits of resources the Association can command. In its gradual approach to wide coverage the Council will review periodically all factors involved in the compilation in the hope of extending coverage when feasible. The basic principle of the MLA Bibliography is that of extended coverage published currently. Items re- ceived too late for inclusion (after 15 January) any year will be entered the next, so that reasonable complete- ness may be achieved in two issues. Over ninety per cent of the important scholarship is thus made available annually on schedule. Such a work must content itself with listing, and not with annotation unless a title requires elucidation. Other bibliographies of special areas of language, chronological periods, or literary figures exist to provide useful annotation and evaluative comment. Attention of specialists is called to bibliographies published annually in such fields and appearing in such periodicals as the Renaissance in Studies in Philology, Shakespeare in the Shakespeare Quarterly, English literature 1660-1800 in Philological Quarterly, Romanticism in English Language Notes, nineteenth-century English literature in Victorian Studies, American literature in American Literature, and American studies in the American Quarterly. Attention is also called to the series edited for the Modern Humanities Research Association, The Year's Work in Modern Language Studies and the Annual Bibliography of English Language and Literature, now approaching current listings. A committee of one hundred has been appointed to produce this bibliography. Its members have sought aid from many helpers, and have adhered to the principle of listing only those items actually seen, in no case relying merely upon publishers' announcements or entries in some other bibliography. Generally they have listed only items published in 1968 and those published in 1967 which came in too late for inclusion last year. Exceptions are noted. The style of entry follows the Bibliographical Style Sheet prepared for the MLA Bibliography by Harrison T. Meserole. Arrangement of the Bibliography for 1968 differs somewhat from that used in bibliographies before 1967. Festschriften and Other Analyzed Collections are listed first. Linguistics items have been gathered into nine linguistics sections and are listed in the second division of the bibliography. Literature entries, grouped by sections, appear in the third and concluding division of the bibliography. The style of entry follows that introduced in the Bibliography for 1967. Arabic numbers have replaced roman to denote the volume number of a journal. Undated items are understood to have been published in 1968. When an issue number of a journal is required for a given entry, it appears in lower-case roman im- mediately after the arabic volume number. An arabic number preceded by F in square brackets following a title refers to an item listed under that number in the Festschriften and Other Analyzed Collections Division which begins the bibliography. A fundamental principle of the bibliography is that each item shall be entered once only, in the section where we believe it will be sought for by the largest group of users. Attention of others is called to it by cross references (these references appear as a series of item numbers at the ends of sections or sub-sections within the bibliography). The bibliography is followed by an author index, prepared by means of electronic data-processing equipment, that provides the name of every author, editor, and compiler represented, to- gether with the number of each item he has produced. Authors are invited to send offprints of articles, monographs, and notices of pertinent books for listing in the Bibliography for 1969, to Harrison T. Meserole, Association Bibliographer, Department of English, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pennsylvania 16802.</page><page sequence="3">THE MLA COMMITTEE ON BIBLIOGRAPHY AND OTHER CONTRIBUTORS TO THE BIBLIOGRAPHY FOR 1968 LINGUISTICS DIVISION WINFRED P. WATTS, Pennsylvania State AND PRISCILLA J. LETTERMAN, Pennsylvania State with the assistance of Jayne K. Kribbs (Pennsylvania State) and Beatrice Reifield (Pennsylvania State) Every author, editor, or compiler who has produced or contributed to an item included in the 1968 Bibliography is listed in the index that follows. Each name listed is succeeded by the number of every item in which that name appears. Forms of the names follow Library of Congress rules whenever possible. Anonymous items have been excluded. The index was compiled at the editorial office of the MLA Inter- national Bibliography and The Pennsylvania State University Com- putation Center. Research facilities were provided by a grant from the Central Research Fund of The Pennsylvania State University.
